salesforce.ae_next_steps: 20/02 MF: Merchant sent Adyen invoices for rate comparison. Needs confirmation on payment method support & fee comparison (on it) + scheduling intro to merchant next week.

narratives.opp_summary: Vision Healthcare is a buy-and-build portfolio company operating ~16 brands across fragmented tech stacks (Magento, CommerceTools, WordPress, and some Shopify). This $82,800 deal involves consolidating 4 brands (Vita Yummy, New Pure, N2, Alpha Foods) onto Shopify Plus under a 3-year multi-brand agreement at $8,280/month. The broader strategic play is to prove out Shopify with the N2 brand as a proof-of-concept, and if successful, migrate the remaining portfolio — covering ~95% of shared functionality — creating significant expansion potential well beyond the initial deal size.
narratives.why_change: Vision Healthcare's current tech stack is highly fragmented across Magento, CommerceTools, WordPress, and existing (improperly licensed) Shopify stores, creating operational inefficiency and technical debt. They have 4 full-time developers dedicated to Magento maintenance for 5+ years, representing a significant ongoing cost. Their earlier Shopify test with Tummy Talks resulted in a meaningful AOV drop due to an unoptimized checkout — particularly around Cash on Delivery features — which demonstrated the gap between their heavily customized Magento checkout and a vanilla Shopify experience. They are also dealing with an existing Shopify Plus contract breach (multiple brands on one license), which creates compliance risk. The COO (Iztok Hvala) has signaled that if the N2 proof-of-concept can match Magento's performance, it opens the door for full portfolio consolidation — suggesting the current multi-platform approach is unsustainable.
narratives.why_shopify: Vision Healthcare sees Shopify Plus as the consolidation platform for their multi-brand portfolio, attracted by the MSA/multi-brand agreement structure that provides preferential group pricing and simplified licensing. During the technical deep-dive, Ben Homer demonstrated that Shopify's Checkout Blocks, Flow, Search & Discovery, payment customization functions, and checkout UI extensions could replicate most of their critical Magento checkout features (subscription popups, cross-sells, COD greylisting, address validation). Iztok explicitly stated they don't need a 'copy paste' — they 'just want to have the same result' — indicating openness to Shopify's approach as long as business outcomes are preserved. They also have a recently acquired brand (Vayami) already on Shopify, giving them some platform familiarity. The potential to move to Shopify Payments and reduce the 0.2% external gateway fee (currently on Adyen at ~$180K/month group processing volume) is an additional financial incentive.
narratives.why_now: The most concrete timeline driver is the proposed contract signature deadline of February 13th, which was set partly because AE Yasmine Fazeli is going on maternity leave. Iztok accepted mid-February as feasible. The N2 brand POC is targeting a Q2 (April) launch in Spain, which creates a natural implementation timeline. However, there is no documented compelling event such as a Magento contract expiration, and the Salesforce 'Compelling Event' field is null. The urgency appears driven more by commercial offer timing and internal portfolio rationalization than by an external forcing function.
narratives.support_needed: Payment method feasibility and rate comparison (merchant sent Adyen invoices, needs confirmation on Shopify Payments support and fee comparison). COD checkout replication confidence for Spain, Italy, and Eastern Europe. Address validation solution for Italian and Spanish markets. Entity and billing structure clarification for multi-brand agreement. Technical architecture follow-up and POC support (COD payment customization and checkout subscription toggle feasibility). Smooth AE transition from Yasmine Fazeli to Maissa Fatte.

questions.text: Do they have business reasons to change?
questions.notes: Multiple calls confirm business reasons: fragmented tech stack across Magento/CommerceTools/WordPress, high maintenance cost (4 FT devs on Magento for 5 years), AOV drop in prior Shopify test, contract breach risk, desire to consolidate portfolio onto one platform.

questions.text: Do they have a defined goal/metric they aim to achieve?
questions.notes: Iztok stated success = matching Magento checkout performance on AOV and conversion for N2 POC. However, no specific quantified targets documented. Processing volume of ~$180K/month on Adyen is known.
questions.solution: Nail down specific AOV and conversion benchmarks for N2 that define POC success.
questions.action: During next call, ask Iztok to share current N2 Magento AOV and conversion rate as the baseline POC success metrics.

questions.text: Have they clearly articulated the problem?
questions.notes: Iztok explicitly stated they've reached 'practically same solutions across all the tech stack' and if N2 works, it covers 95% of functionality for all brands. The fragmented multi-platform setup is clearly not sustainable.

questions.text: Have they quantified the impact of the problem?
questions.notes: Implied consequences include continued high dev costs, compliance risk from Shopify contract breach, and inability to scale acquisitions efficiently. However, no one explicitly stated 'if we don't consolidate, X bad thing happens by Y date.'
questions.solution: Quantify the cost of inaction — ongoing Magento dev spend, risk exposure from license breach, opportunity cost of slow brand launches.
questions.action: Ask Iztok what maintaining the current multi-platform setup costs annually.

questions.text: Is there a compelling event driving urgency?
questions.notes: Salesforce Compelling Event field is null. The February 13th contract deadline was artificially set around AE maternity leave. No external event identified.
questions.solution: Discover if there is a Magento license renewal, upcoming acquisition, or board-level mandate creating a natural deadline.
questions.action: Ask Iztok directly: 'Is there a Magento contract renewal or any board-level timeline we should be aware of?'

questions.text: Have both parties agreed on what success looks like?
questions.notes: Metrics around checkout performance (AOV, conversion) discussed extensively. No formal mutual agreement on specific KPIs.
questions.solution: Create a simple success criteria document listing agreed-upon metrics for the N2 POC.
questions.action: Draft a 1-page POC success criteria doc and share with Iztok for validation.

questions.text: Is the 'justify the change' narrative complete?
questions.notes: The checkout performance concern is clearly compelling enough. But without quantified goals and cost-of-inaction, the full 'justify change' narrative isn't locked in.
questions.solution: Build an ROI narrative: dev cost savings + payment fee savings + faster brand launch velocity vs. current state.
questions.action: Prepare a lightweight business case comparing current multi-platform TCO vs. consolidated Shopify Plus costs.

questions.text: Have we identified the Economic Buyer?
questions.notes: Iztok Hvala (COO) is the primary contact with significant decision authority. However, Vision Healthcare is a buy-and-build portfolio company, suggesting there may be a CEO, CFO, or PE/board-level approver above Iztok. Joost Hunfeld (also COO) has not appeared on any calls.
questions.solution: Clarify whether Iztok can sign independently or if there's a higher-level approval needed.
questions.action: Ask Iztok: 'Beyond yourself, who else needs to approve this agreement?' and clarify Joost Hunfeld's role.

questions.text: Do we understand the signing authority and entity?
questions.notes: The billing entity question is still unresolved (New Pure vs. German entity). No clarity on who specifically signs the contract.
questions.solution: Determine the signing entity and authorized signatory.
questions.action: Follow up with Iztok on entity determination and ask who will be the contract signatory.

questions.text: Do we have direct access to the EB?
questions.notes: Iztok has been on all 3 calls and is highly engaged. Direct access is clearly established.

questions.text: Have we mapped the full buying committee?
questions.notes: We have access to Iztok (COO) and Boštjan (Head of IT), but not to Joost Hunfeld (other COO) or any higher-level decision-maker.
questions.solution: Map the full buying committee and request introductions.
questions.action: Ask Iztok to introduce Maissa to Joost Hunfeld and any other stakeholders.

questions.text: Do we understand EB's personal priorities?
questions.notes: Iztok cares about: checkout performance matching Magento, payment cost optimization, multi-brand operational efficiency, risk-free migration via POC approach. But we don't know what the ultimate economic buyer (if above Iztok) cares about.
questions.solution: Validate EB priorities at the holding company / PE level.
questions.action: Ask Iztok what metrics or outcomes his leadership/board would need to see to approve a full portfolio migration.

questions.text: Do we understand the budget and procurement process?
questions.notes: No information on formal budget allocation process, fiscal year timing, or how Vision Healthcare makes technology investment decisions at the portfolio level.
questions.solution: Understand their budgeting and procurement process for cross-brand technology decisions.
questions.action: Ask Iztok about budget cycles and how cross-brand technology investments are typically approved.

questions.text: Do we know the decision process?
questions.notes: Implicit process: technical validation via N2 POC → commercial agreement → contract signing. No formal process documented.
questions.solution: Formalize the decision process steps with the buyer.
questions.action: Propose a mutual action plan outlining: technical validation → commercial alignment → legal/entity setup → signature.

questions.text: Have we identified all decision participants?
questions.notes: Known: Iztok Hvala (COO), Boštjan Knez (Head of IT). Joost Hunfeld not on calls. No visibility into legal, finance, or PE-level involvement.
questions.solution: Map the full buying committee including legal, finance, and any board/PE oversight.
questions.action: Ask Iztok to confirm all stakeholders involved in contract review and approval.

questions.text: Is there an agreed decision timeline?
questions.notes: Original Feb 13 deadline passed. Current Salesforce close date is March 31. No updated timeline from buyer.
questions.solution: Re-establish a clear decision date with the buyer.
questions.action: Confirm with Iztok: 'Are you still targeting a decision this quarter? What needs to happen before you can sign?'

questions.text: Is the timeline backed by an event or consequence?
questions.notes: N2 Q2 (April) launch target creates natural implementation timeline, but no hard external deadline identified.
questions.solution: Connect the decision timeline to the N2 Q2 launch.
questions.action: Calculate backwards from Q2 N2 launch to determine latest viable contract signature date.

questions.text: Have they evaluated Shopify before?
questions.notes: Tested Shopify previously with Tummy Talks — AOV drops due to unoptimized checkout. Also have Vayami on Shopify.

questions.text: Do we understand the consequence of no decision?
questions.notes: Implied: continued fragmented stack, ongoing Magento dev costs, unresolved Shopify license breach. Not explicitly stated.
questions.solution: Surface the cost of inaction.
questions.action: Ask Iztok: 'What happens if this decision gets pushed to Q3 or later?'

questions.text: Has the decision process been validated with the buyer?
questions.notes: Decision process has been implied through conversation flow but never formally confirmed.
questions.solution: Get explicit buyer agreement on the path to close.
questions.action: Share a written mutual action plan and ask Iztok to confirm or modify.

questions.text: Do we know the decision criteria?
questions.notes: Key criteria surfaced: checkout performance matching Magento AOV/conversion, COD support, payment cost competitiveness vs Adyen, multi-brand pricing, address validation. No formal list from buyer.
questions.solution: Ask the buyer to share or confirm their formal evaluation criteria.
questions.action: Ask Iztok: 'Beyond checkout performance and payment costs, what other factors will drive your final decision?'

questions.text: Are the product requirements well-understood?
questions.notes: D2C capabilities discussed extensively. B2B and retail not discussed — Salesforce shows null B2B/Retail GMV.
questions.solution: Confirm whether B2B or retail/POS are relevant for any brands.
questions.action: Ask Iztok if any brands have B2B or retail needs beyond D2C.

questions.text: Are the technical complications known?
questions.notes: Extensive discussion: COD payment customization, greylisting logic, address validation for Italian/Spanish postal systems, checkout subscription toggle, multi-market conditional payment display, Adyen integration.

questions.text: Have payment implications been discussed?
questions.notes: Payments discussed in all three calls. Current Adyen processing at ~$180K/month, 0.2% external gateway fee, interest in Shopify Payments rate comparison. Merchant sent Adyen invoices.
questions.action: Complete Shopify Payments vs. Adyen rate comparison and present to merchant.

questions.text: Is there a mutual action plan?
questions.notes: No mutual action plan formally created or shared. Process has been ad-hoc.
questions.solution: Create and share a MAP with clear milestones, owners, and dates.
questions.action: Draft a MAP covering: payment comparison → technical validation → entity determination → contract review → signature.

questions.text: Are we shaping the criteria in our favor?
questions.notes: Ben demonstrated Shopify's native capabilities. MSA structure was Shopify's proposal. No evidence of proactively shaping criteria vs. a competitor.
questions.solution: Frame the evaluation around Shopify's unique strengths (multi-brand MSA, checkout extensibility, ecosystem).
questions.action: Prepare a 'Why Shopify for multi-brand portfolios' positioning document.

questions.text: Do we know who created the criteria?
questions.notes: Unclear whether the criteria came from Iztok, Boštjan, a consultant, or a formal RFP process.
questions.solution: Understand the origin of their evaluation framework.
questions.action: Ask Iztok: 'Did you develop these requirements internally, or is there a broader evaluation framework involved?'

questions.text: Do we understand the procurement process?
questions.notes: No discussion of procurement process, legal review, or how contracts flow through Vision Healthcare. Entity question unresolved.
questions.solution: Map the full procurement/legal process.
questions.action: Ask Iztok about internal contract approval process, reviewers, and typical timelines.

questions.text: Are there likely redlines or legal concerns?
questions.notes: Multi-entity portfolio company likely with PE backing — redlines on 3-year commitment probable. Existing contract breach introduces legal complexity.
questions.solution: Proactively prepare by involving Shopify legal early.
questions.action: Flag to Shopify legal that this is a multi-entity deal with existing contract breach requiring resolution.

questions.text: Do we know the legal review timeline?
questions.notes: No information on legal review timelines.
questions.solution: Get an estimate from the buyer.
questions.action: Ask Iztok how long legal/contract reviews typically take at Vision Healthcare.

questions.text: Is the paper process on track?
questions.notes: Original Feb 13 deadline passed. No updated timeline for contract completion.
questions.solution: Re-establish paper process timeline.
questions.action: Align on a new target signature date working back from Q2 N2 launch.

questions.text: Are commercial terms agreed?
questions.notes: Commercial terms discussed in Call 3: 3-year term, $8,280/month for 4 brands, consolidated MSA. But contract hasn't been drafted or shared.
questions.solution: Move from verbal commercial terms to actual contract.
questions.action: Generate the contract based on agreed terms and send for review.

questions.text: Has the contract been sent?
questions.notes: Contract has not been sent. Commercial terms discussed verbally only.
questions.solution: Send contract promptly.
questions.action: Prepare and send the MSA/contract to Iztok once entity determination is confirmed.

questions.text: Is there a target signature date?
questions.notes: Original Feb 13 target passed. No new target date established. Salesforce close date March 31 appears to be internal target only.
questions.solution: Get buyer commitment to a new signature date.
questions.action: Propose a signature target date tied to N2 Q2 launch requirements.

questions.text: Is the pain clearly identified?
questions.notes: Extensively documented: fragmented multi-platform tech stack, 4 FT Magento developers for 5 years, AOV drop in prior Shopify checkout test, complex COD requirements, Shopify license breach, ISP-level traffic blocking in Italy, high payment processing costs.

questions.text: Have they tried to solve this before?
questions.notes: They tested Shopify with Tummy Talks — checkout was unoptimized and caused significant AOV drop. They reverted/didn't proceed.

questions.text: Does the pain affect the broader business?
questions.notes: Pain affects operations through: high developer costs, slow time-to-market for new brands, inconsistent customer experiences, suboptimal checkout conversion, payment processing inefficiency.

questions.text: Do we know who is affected?
questions.notes: IT team (Boštjan, 4 Magento devs) and COO (Iztok) are clearly affected. Marketing, finance, and other team impacts not discussed.
questions.solution: Understand broader organizational impact.
questions.action: Ask about how the fragmented stack affects marketing, finance, and operations teams.

questions.text: Is there urgency around the pain?
questions.notes: Urgency around N2 Q2 launch target, but broader consolidation doesn't have a hard deadline. Iztok is motivated but not under visible external pressure.
questions.solution: Connect the consolidation to a business urgency.
questions.action: Ask Iztok if there's a board-level timeline or cost reduction target driving the consolidation.

questions.text: Have alternatives been explored?
questions.notes: Could stay on Magento (status quo). CommerceTools is in their stack but not discussed as a consolidation option. No other platforms mentioned.
questions.solution: Understand if CommerceTools or any other platform is being considered.
questions.action: Ask directly: 'Are you evaluating any other platform besides Shopify for this consolidation?'

questions.text: Is the pain acute enough to drive action now?
questions.notes: The 'now' is driven by N2 needing a platform and the consolidation opportunity. Not a hard external event.
questions.solution: Strengthen the 'why now' with quantified cost of delay.
questions.action: Help Iztok calculate: 'Every month you delay saves/costs $X in dev costs, payment fees, and launch velocity.'

questions.text: Is Shopify uniquely positioned to solve the pain?
questions.notes: Shopify's multi-brand MSA, checkout extensibility, and platform breadth position it well. But Tummy Talks AOV drop and COD complexity show this is conditional on proving the checkout can perform.
questions.solution: Ensure the N2 POC addresses all critical checkout features.
questions.action: Create a POC requirements checklist mapping each Magento feature to its Shopify solution.

questions.text: Have we identified a Champion?
questions.notes: Iztok Hvala (COO) shows strong champion characteristics — driving evaluation, deeply engaged, accepted timelines, articulated 'if N2 works, we migrate everything' vision. But ability to push internally is unvalidated.
questions.solution: Test Iztok's champion qualities by asking him to take internal action.
questions.action: Ask Iztok to share the mutual action plan with his leadership and confirm alignment.

questions.text: Does the Champion have credibility and influence?
questions.notes: As COO, Iztok presumably has significant credibility. He appears to make technology and vendor decisions. But we don't know his standing with the board or PE firm.
questions.solution: Understand Iztok's internal political position.
questions.action: Observe whether Iztok can deliver on commitments as a proxy for his organizational influence.

questions.text: Has the Champion shared insider information?
questions.notes: Iztok provided extensive insider knowledge: Tummy Talks test failure details, internal tech stack decisions, Adyen payment structure, brand standardization status, new Vayami acquisition, and the contract breach.

questions.text: Is the Champion connected to the EB?
questions.notes: Iztok is a COO and appears to be a key decision-maker himself. Joost Hunfeld (other COO) listed but hasn't been on calls. Authority structure above Iztok unclear.
questions.solution: Determine the full authority structure.
questions.action: Ask Iztok: 'Who else needs to say yes for this to move forward?'

questions.text: Has the Champion introduced us to decision-makers?
questions.notes: We have not been introduced to any decision-maker beyond Iztok and Boštjan. Joost Hunfeld has not been on calls.
questions.solution: Request introduction to Joost and other decision-makers.
questions.action: Ask Iztok: 'Should we include Joost Hunfeld or anyone else in our next discussion?'

questions.text: Is the Champion selling internally on our behalf?
questions.notes: No evidence of Iztok offering to bring Shopify into a board meeting or internal stakeholder discussion.
questions.solution: Ask if there's a formal internal review where Shopify's involvement would help.
questions.action: Offer to prepare materials Iztok could present internally, or join an internal stakeholder meeting.

questions.text: Do we understand the Champion's personal motivation?
questions.notes: Iztok appears motivated by: reducing tech stack complexity, proving a scalable platform for future acquisitions, optimizing payment costs, enabling faster brand launches. Personal career incentive likely aligns.
questions.solution: Validate Iztok's personal motivation.
questions.action: In a 1:1 moment, ask Iztok: 'What does a successful outcome here look like for you personally?'

questions.text: Have we identified the competition?
questions.notes: Salesforce Competitor field is null. No competitors mentioned in any calls. Evaluation appears to be Shopify vs. status quo (Magento).
questions.solution: Directly ask if other platforms are being evaluated.
questions.action: Ask Iztok: 'Beyond Shopify and staying on Magento, are you evaluating any other platforms?'

questions.text: Is 'do nothing' a real option?
questions.notes: Staying on Magento is implicitly an option — they have 4 developers and it works. The POC approach formalizes 'prove it before we commit.'
questions.solution: Quantify the cost of status quo to make 'do nothing' less attractive.
questions.action: Build a TCO comparison: current Magento multi-platform costs vs. consolidated Shopify costs over 3 years.

questions.text: Have alternatives been ruled out?
questions.notes: CommerceTools is already in their tech stack but was never discussed as a consolidation option.
questions.solution: Understand if CommerceTools was considered and ruled out.
questions.action: Ask: 'You have some brands on CommerceTools — was that considered as a consolidation platform?'

questions.text: Do we understand the competitive landscape?
questions.notes: No discussion of why specific alternatives are or aren't being evaluated.
questions.solution: Understand the competitive landscape.
questions.action: Ask Iztok what led them to focus on Shopify specifically for consolidation vs. other options.

questions.text: Do we have a competitive advantage?
questions.notes: Without knowing who the competition is, cannot assess win/loss drivers beyond Shopify vs. status quo. Key risk is checkout performance gap from Tummy Talks test.
questions.solution: Identify competitive threats and differentiation. Focus on beating 'do nothing' by proving checkout parity.
questions.action: Prepare competitive positioning for N2 POC.

calls.ai_summary: This sales meeting focused on a potential multi-brand migration to Shopify. Shopify proposed a phased approach using a Master Service Agreement (MSA) for incremental licensing and preferential group pricing across Vision Healthcare's 16+ brands. Vision Healthcare expressed strong interest, targeting a Q2 launch for brand N2 as a proof-of-concept. They highlighted a previous test with Tummy Talks where an unoptimized Shopify checkout led to a significant AOV drop compared to their current Magento setup, particularly regarding custom Cash on Delivery features.

This meeting focused on migrating and replicating the buyer's existing Magento checkout functionality onto Shopify Plus. The seller highlighted Shopify's native tools like Checkout Blocks, Flow, and Search & Discovery. The buyer presented critical Magento checkout features including subscription pop-ups, product bundles, conditional grey-listing for payment methods, additional services, and robust address validation. Key concerns included implementing conditional payment fees and complex address validation.

This meeting centered on consolidating the buyers' four brands (Vita Yummy, New Pure, Alpha Foods, N2) into a single three-year multi-brand agreement. The seller offered a discounted monthly rate of $8,280, a $1,000 saving from the usual $9,200, contingent on contract signing by February 13th. Buyers accepted this timeline but require internal coordination to choose the main billing entity and clarify current fees versus the proposed consolidated structure. They expressed keen interest in exploring Shopify Payments to reduce transaction fees.
